section.title: Introduction
section.para: Without using Atomik, one way of doing things would have been to create a file per page. The page logic (i.e. connecting to a database, handling form data...) would have been at the top of the file followed by the HTML.

example.title: A file in the old way
example.programlisting:
<?php
						if (count($_POST)) {
							echo 'Form data received!';
						}
					?>
					<form>
						<input type="text" name="data" />
						<input type="submit" value="send" />
					</form>

section.para: This is BAD!! The application logic and the presentation layer should always be separated.
Now let's imagine that rather than directly doing both part in the same file we split it. We would have three file: one with the logic, one with the HTML and on that include both.

example.title: Splitting into multiple files

section.para: Now replace the third file (the one with the includes) with Atomik and you'll have the concept behind Atomik. The logic script is named an action and the html one a template.

section.title: Actions
section.para: Actions are stored in the /app/actions directory. Both the action and the template filename must have the same name.
The content of the action file is free. It can be anything you want. So you just do your logic as you used to.
section.note: Be aware that action run in their own scope and not in the global scope as you might think.
section.para: Variables declare in the action are forwarded to the template. If you want to keep some variables private (i.e. which will only be available in your action) prefixed them with an underscore.
section.note: You shouldn't use echo or write any HTML code inside an action. As said before, the goal of an action is to separate the logic from the presentation. Thus mix-in both in the action file would be a non-sense!

section.title: Templates
section.para: Templates are stored in the /app/templates directory.
The content of the template file is, as the action file, free. It should mostly be text or HTML (or any presentation content, such as XML).
PHP can be used to print variables from the action or to provide presentation logic like loops.

section.title: Calling actions or templates programmatically
section.para: When executing a request, the action and/or the template associated to it are automatically called. You can however call other actions or render other templates using Atomik's API.
The most useful use of this it to render partial templates, small part of presentation code that is reusable.

section.title: Executing actions
section.para: To execute an action use the Atomik::execute() method. It takes as first argument the action name.
By default, if a template with the same name is found, it is rendered and the return value of the execute() method is the template output.
If no template is found or false is used as second argument, the return value is an array containing all public variables from the action.

section.title: Rendering templates
section.para: To render a template use the Atomik::render() method.
It takes as first argument the template name and optionally as second argument an array of key/value pairs representing variables.
The method returns the template output.
For more information on both methods, see the API reference.
